Her main activity is to purchase cassave and process it into flour (cassava flour), one of the basic foods in south Togo. Madam N. has shown proved to be an honest and trustworthy woman through the repayments without incidents of her first two credits granted. The flour production is a very hard activity with many risks of injury due to a lack of suitable tools. Buying a tool, the rough, with a credit of $750 will provide an important opportunity to increase her production and income. The rough could even be rented to other women in the area. This will provide to them significant income. Having the rough avoids making a 3 to 5 km trek to have the cassava rasped. The remainder of the credit will serve to buy cassava in other farms to have sufficient raw materials for the regular production all over the year.

Agée de 35 ans environ, elle est veuve et mère de trois (03) enfants. N’ayant pas eu la chance de s’instruire, Mme Massan N. a juré qu’aucun de ses enfants ne restera analphabète comme elle et se bat pour leur éducation. Très intelligente et très bien appliquée, elle reste l’une des femmes de référence dans le village de Ahonkpé où elle vit avec ses orphelins. Son activité principale est l’achat de manioc et sa transformation en gari (farine de manioc), l’un des aliments de base au Sud du Togo. Mme Massan N. a fait preuve d’honnêteté et de femme de confiance à travers les remboursements sans incidents de ses deux premiers crédits obtenus. La fabrication du gari est une activité très pénible avec tous les risques de blessures dus au manuel traditionnel de râpage du manioc car ne disposant pas de râpeuse. Le financement d’une râpeuse et d’un fonds de crédit de $ 750 serait un apport très capital pour augmenter sa production et facto ses revenus. La râpeuse pourra même être louée à d’autres femmes de la localité, ce qui lui procurerait d’autres recettes non négligeables. La disposition sur place de la râpeuse évitera de parcourir de longue distance de 3 à 5 km pour aller se faire râper le manioc. Le reste des fonds servira à acheter des champs de manioc afin de disposer suffisamment de matière première pour la production régulière sur toute l’année.

loans.use: To buy rough and cassava farms

loans.name: Komla

texts.en:
Soon aged 45, Komla A., reseller of construction gravel for nearly ten years is married to two women and father to five children and six others who he supports.  His work has not had great success in times past due to his not owning his own truck.  He has worked up to this point for the truck owners who set the prices themselves.  To improve his situation, he has received a small credit of $400USD which he has already paid back despite his numerous family responibilities. 

Mr. A. is asking for a loan of $1200 to buy a truck with which he will transport gravel thereby setting his own transport fees. He plans to repay this loan in 15 months.  This is a man with ample experience in this field of work and on who has previously demonstrated both his expertise as a driver as well as his business experience and reliability.

loans.use: Purchase of a gravel truck

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: The loan will be used to enlarge the pharmacy and buy medicines to supply it.

loans.name: Thuy

texts.en: Miss Thuy is 31 and her husband is 36 years old. They have a child who is 1 year of age. They have to support his mother. They have land for growing rice, which is 1500 square meters. Her husband works as a day laborer but the work is not stable. So her selling rice cakes at the small market is important to increase their income by about $1/person/month, which brings their average income to $10 per person/month. Now Miss Thuy wants to borrow $75 for selling rice cakes. She will repay the loan monthly.

loans.use: Selling rice cakes

loans.name: Rosa

texts.es:
Rosa is 45 years old and has 5 children. Her husband works in the countryside as a laborer. Rosa makes tamales and "atole", a traditional beverage prepared with corn and flavors. She used to sell this in the city market, going stall to stall. With the loan she hopes to be able to buy materials to prepare her food and drinks. She is part of the group Grupo Solidario 9, together with Mrs. Micaela L. G., who makes "pozol", ( corn cooked and ground and mixed with water), and sells it in the market. Both hope to buy more cooking utensils to prepare their products in better conditions, and arrange a place in their homes to sell their products.

ROSA tiene 45 años , cinco hijos , su esposo trabaja en el campo como jornalero , ella hace tamales y atole( bebida tradicional , preparado con maíz y saborizantes que le dan color y sabor ) que posteriormente vende en el mercado de la ciudad de manera ambulante.Con el préstamo espera poder comprar materia prima para preparar sus productos .Pertenece a Grupo Solidario 9 junto con doña Micaela López Gómez (hace pozol (maíz cocido y molido que se bate en agua ) y lo vende en el mercado ) Ambas esperan con el préstamo comprar más utensilios de cocina para preparar en mejores condiciones sus alimentos y además adaptar un lugar en sus casas para vender También ahí sus productos.

Translated by Kiva volunteer, Emily Charnes

loans.use: To sell foods typical to the region

loans.name: Anita

texts.en:
Anita C. C. belongs to a village bank called “Sumaqcha,” which is Quechua (native language) for “Beautiful Bank.”

Anita is a business woman. She sells a variety of different products to a variety of different clients, enabling her to capitalize on several markets. Anita sells clothing, ice cream, cigarettes, and coca leaves. Coca leaves are a very important part of Andean culture here in Ayacucho, Peru. They are used to make a tea or simply chewed and are known for their many medicinal benefits including alleviation of hunger, facilitation of metabolism, and help with altitude sickness. In addition to all of this, Anita also sells fresh fish by the box once every month to individual customers and restaurants.

For ten years, Anita has been running her own business, but the truth is that her experience goes back much, much further. Her mother also sold coca leaves, as well as fruit, in the local markets, and Anita grew up watching and learning. Just as she helped her mother, today Anita’s four children also help her in the markets. One daughter is in charge of selling clothes, another is in charge of ice cream, and the other two help where they can. However, because Anita insists that school comes before anything else, they are only allowed to help on Saturdays and Sundays.

Everything Anita does, she does for her children’s future. When her husband left the five of them some years ago, Anita had no choice but to work twice as hard to provide for her family as a newly single mother. Her goal is to see all four of her children through to professional degrees. As a means to accomplish this, Anita’s professional goal is to open up her own small grocery store. She has plans to sell her car in order to invest the money in a store. She also hopes to take out loans from her village bank to facilitate the growth of her business. This is why, she says, she loves to be a part of her village bank. She gives thanks that it has inspired her to be more responsible. Anita is hoping to receive a loan of $1,000, with which she will be able to buy larger quantities of goods and also work towards her goal of opening a grocery store.

loans.use: To buy larger quantities of goods and also work towards opening a grocery store

loans.name: Ana Silvia

texts.es:
Ana Silvia is a woman who likes to fight for what she wants. And from the beginning she wanted to give her children an education so they could succeed. That's why 6 years ago she began selling skin creams, perfumes and cosmetics to her neighbors and friends. She gradually began to acquire customers who bought from her often.

Now, Ana is applying for a loan of $1,100 USD, which she's willing to repay within 6 months. This money will be used to buy products so that she can do demonstrations to groups of neighbors who come together to her house. With your help Ana may use this holiday season to be able to make available more merchandise, and make enough money to buy everything she needs for her home and her family's expenses.

Translated from Spanish by Mayra Gould, Kiva volunteer.

Ana Silvia es una mujer que le gusta luchar por lo que quiere. Y desD. un inicio quiso darle a sus hijos educación para que pudieran salir adelante. Es por eso que hace 6 años que comenzó a vender cremas para L. piel, perfumes y cosméticos a sus vecinas y amigas. Y poco a poco comenzó a adquirir clientas que le compraban constantemente.

Sin embargo actualmente está solicitando un crédito D. US $1,100 que está dispuesta a pagarlos en un plazo D. 6 meses con este dinero podrá comprar mercancía y así poder hacer demostraciones a grupos D. vecinas que se juntan en una casa. Con tu ayuda Ana podrá aprovechar esta temporada naviD.ña para poder colocar más mercancía y así tener dinero para comprar todo lo necesario para su casa y para los gastos D. su familia.

loans.use: To purchase merchandise in order to sustain her business. (Comprar mercancía para poder surtir su negocio)

loans.name: Husna

texts.en:
Husna, age 32, is married with 5 children (ages 15, 13, 10, 7, and 4). She owns a business of selling clothing. She began this business 6 years ago and now she is able to make about $530 a month from this trade. She sells the clothes from 10am to 3pm daily.

In the past, Husna was able to take out a loan from BRAC Tanzania to increase her business. Having paid this back successfully, she now hopes to take out a new loan to buy more clothing stock.

Husna is a member of the loan group Kichangani, whose members ensure one another and keep eachother accountable in paying back their loans.

loans.use: To buy clothing stock

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy more tomatoes to sell

loans.name: James

texts.en:
James N. E. is a teacher and a retailer. He is single and has no children. To supplement his modest teacher's salary, James sells soaps, sugar, corn meal, and other provisions around Cape Coast Polytechnic. He is requesting a loan of $525 to buy a wider variety of soaps and food products for sale.

James is also a member of a lending group called “Calvary Group”, which consists of 11 members in Cape Coast, Ghana.

loans.use: To buy a wider variety of soaps and food products for re-sale

loans.name: Vilfredo

texts.es:
With the help of his beloved parents, Vilfredo was able to obtain his own work tools so that he could carry out his daily tasks around his city. He has a young daughter and would like to increase his earnings so that he could provide her with wellbeing. For this reason, he decided to set up a small pharmacy in his house so that his dear wife can practice the profession that she is so passionate about and for which she prepared at a prestigious university in her city.

Translated from Spanish by Elizabeth Casian, Kiva Volunteer.

Con ayuda de sus queridos padres Vilfredo, a podido adquirir su herramienta de trabajo para desempañarse a diario por los alrededores de su ciudad. Tiene una pequeña niña y desea incrementar sus ingresos para otorgarle mayor bienestar por esa razón ha decidido instalar una pequeña farmacia en casa a fin de que su querida esposa ejerza la profesión que tanto la apasiona y para la cual se preparó en una prestigiosa universidad de su ciudad.

loans.use: Set up a small, home pharmacy

loans.name: Manzanayocc Group

texts.es:
The Communal Manzanayocc Bank is a newer bank that has 4 cycles and 13 partners. The partners are from the Manzanayocc community that belongs to the Socos District and is 3 hours outside of the city of Ayacucho. The inhabitants of the community mainly raise cattle and produce milk, in addition to agriculture.

The partners are involved in diverse businesses such as raising cattle, milk production, livestock sales and agriculture.

The partners need different levels of loans ranging from approximately $100 and up, making up the total in the Communal Bank.

The loan proceeds will be invested in the purchase of medicine for livestock, rennet (a curdling agent), fertilizer, and smaller animals.

The dream of the partners is to have a great stable, to produce more, and to offer a good education to their children.

Translated from Spanish by Kara Gibson, Kiva volunteer.

El Banco Comunal Manzanayocc es un Banco joven que tiene 4 ciclos y 13 socias. Las socias son de la comunidad de Manzanayocc que pertenece al Distrito de Socos y queda a 3 horas de la ciudad de Ayacucho. Los pobladores de esta comunidad se dedican principalmente a la crianza de ganado vacuno y la producción de leche, además a la agricultura.

Las socias realizan diversos negocios como crianza de ganado vacuno, producción de lácteos, venta de animales y agricultura

Las socias necesitan diferentes montos de préstamos como 300 soles, 600 soles, 900 soles, haciendo un total de 4800 soles en el Banco Comunal.

Sus prestamos serán invertidos en la compra de medicina para su ganado, cuajo, abono y animales menores.

El sueño de las socias es tener un establo grande, producir más, y brindar una buena educación a sus hijos.

loans.use: Purchase of medicine for livestock, rennet (a curdling agent), fertilizer, and smaller animals.

loans.name: Cleide

texts.es:
Cleide is a member of the Santa Rita Communal Bank (first loan: www.kiva.org/app.php?page=businesses&action=about&id=29542&_tpos=1&_tpg=1). She is married, 38 years old and has two children. She runs a carpentry business along with her husband, fulfilling orders to make distinct furniture items. In the past two months they've received orders from institutions, which has helped them increase their earnings. She also works teaching the elderly how to read and write. Cleide is requesting a loan of 1000 soles ($375), which she plans to use to purchase cedar and devilwood. Her dreams are to enlarge her shop and open a furniture store in the city center.

Translated from Spanish by Marty Greenstein, Kiva Volunteer

Primer préstamo: http://www.kiva.org/app.php?page=businesses&action=about&id=29542&_tpos=1&_tpg=1

Cleide es socia del Banco Comunal Santa Rita.

Cleide es casada, tiene 38 años y 2 hijos, Cleide junto a su esposo tienen una carpintería, ubicada en un asentamiento humano, realizan trabajos a pedidos de distintos muebles, en los últimos meses tuvo pedidos de instituciones con lo cual sus ingresos aumentaron. Además Cleide trabaja alfabetizando a personas mayores.

Cleide necesita un préstamo de 1000 soles, dinero que será invertido en la compra de madera cedro y diablo.

Los sueños de Cleide son ampliar su taller y abrir una tienda de muebles en el centro de la ciudad.

loans.use: Purchase cedar and devilwood to make furniture / Cleide necesita un préstamo de 1000 soles, dinero que será invertido en la compra de madera cedro y diablo.

loans.name: Franz Tamayo Group

texts.es:
The Pan-American focal center (of Pro-Mujer Bolivia) is located in the city of El Alto. The "Franz Tamayo" association belongs to this center; a group that works with a lot of responsibility toward their loans and internal activities. Among those inside the group, many lack basic services in their houses. For example Doña Catita can not rely on drinking water which should be supplied by public water basins. This is a problem because they only supply water in the mornings and even then only for a few hours. She longs to be able to have this service in her residence.

The main activity of this group is the weaving of blankets and making of ‘polleras’ (typical clothing of some regions of Bolivia) that they then sell in the market called ‘16th of July’ of the city of El Alto. At present they want to be able to expand their merchandise and to offer other types of products, such as shoes and sweaters. They need greater capital for the acquisition of materials to make these. They have confidence to improve their income, and in this manner to also improve the quality of life of their families

Translated from Spanish by B, Kiva Volunteer.

El centro focal de Panamericana se encuentra ubicado en la ciudad de El Alto, a este pertenece la asociación “Franz Tamayo” que trabajan con mucha responsabilidad en cuanto a sus cuotas de crédito y actividades internas. Dentro el grupo muchas de ellas carecen de servicios básicos en sus casas por ejemplo doña Catita no cuenta con agua potable por lo que debe abastecerse de agua en piletas publicas, echo que es un problema ya que el abastecimiento solo lo dan por las mañanas y solo por algunas horas, ella anhela poder contar con este servicio en su domicilio.

La actividad principal de este grupo es el tejido de mantas y confección de polleras (vestimenta típica de algunas regiones de Bolivia) que luego las venden en la feria 16 de julio de la ciudad de El Alto. Actualmente desean poder ampliar su mercadería y ofrecer otro tipo de productos como ser zapatos y chompas por lo que necesitan mayor capital para la adquisición de materia prima para la confección de estos. Tienen la seguridad de mejorar sus ingresos, de esta manera mejorar también la calidad de vida de sus familias

loans.use: To buy materials to make shoes and sweaters for sale.

loans.name: Román

texts.es:
Mr. Roman J. is 53 years old, and has been married for 26 years to Mrs. Julia Villasanti, age 47. The couple has six children of whom four are living at home and the other two are working abroad; the children living with them are attending primary and secondary school.

Roman is at the forefront of a small store and meat market which began in 2003 with the savings from his previous work. His wife assists him in his business; she prepares dishes such as pies, cakes and breaded meat.

He is seeking a loan to purchase meat, sausages, rice, flour, noodles, peaches, sugar, milk, oil, herb and soft drinks. This way he can supply his business and give his customers a wider range of products.

Translated from Spanish by Jennie R. Campos, Kiva Volunteer.

El Sr. Roman J. de 53 años de edad, esta casado hace 26 años con la Sra. Julia Villasanti de 47 años de edad. El matrimonio tiene seis hijos de los cuales cuatro estan viviendo con ellos y los otro dos están trabajando en el exterior; los hijos que vive con ellos están cursando la primaria y secundaria.

Don Roman se encuentra al frente de una Despensa y carnicería en la cual se inició en el año de 2003 con un capital de ahorro, fruto de su anterior trabajo. En dicho negocio recibe la ayuda de su esposa, quien tambien se dedica a la elaboración de comestibles como empanada, tortas y milanesas.

El cliente solicita el préstamo para la compra de carnes, chorizo, arroz, harina, fideos, dulce de durazno, azucar, leche, aceite, yerba y gaseosas en general. De este modo para surtir su negocio y dar a sus clientes una mayor variedad de productos.

loans.use: To buy shoes, meat, sausages, rice, flour, noodles, peaches, sugar, milk, oil, sardines, and herbs.

loans.name: Mr. Duch Chark Village Bank Group

texts.en:
The Village Bank, consisting of 26 people, is located in Kandal Leu Village in Kandal Province and Mr. Duch C. is the Village Bank President selected by the members. The members plan to use the loan for a variety of purposes; for example, Mr. Duch C. plans to buy fertilizer for his farmland and more bean seeds for cultivation.  His wife, Mrs. Khuth Saron, helps her husband on the farm.

Mr. C. is 42 years old and the father of four children, two of whom help their parents in the field while the other two are attending high school. 

In this village bank loan, one member has an end-of-term loan and the rest have monthly payment loans. This member is not required to pay any principal on the loan until the very end of the loan term. End-of-term (EoT) loans are AMK's main product because it is the most beneficial to Cambodia's poor. It allows them to repay portions of the principal whenever they are financially able to. Most clients start to make payments many months before the end of the loan term. Almost all of AMK's clients make their payments on time. AMK has a delinquency rate of only 0.09% and AMK has a default rate of 0% on Kiva.

loans.use: To buy fertilizers for the farm and more bean seeds for cultivating.

loans.name: José

texts.es:
José P. tiene 52 años de edad, está casado con la Ladislaa Villasboa, tienen 5 hijos, todos ellos estudian en el colegio de la ciudad. José vive con su familia hace más de 30 años en su casa propia.

José aprendió el oficio desde muy joven, trabajando con su padre, de quién heredó la profesión de zapatero. Actualmente cuenta con su propio negocio desde hace más de 25 años. Pretende utilizar el crédito para la compra de suelas y cuero (materia prima) para la producción de zapatos para damas y caballeros, que realiza en gran cantidad, ya que tiene muchos pedidos, por la buena calidad de sus productos.
texts.en:
José P. is 52 years old and married to Ladislaa Vallasboa. They have 5 children, all of whom attend school in the city. José has lived in his house with his family for over 30 years. José learned his trade as a young child, working with his father, from whom he inherited shoemaking as a trade. He has actually had his own shoemaking business for the past 25 years. He claims that he will use this loan in order to buy soles and leather (a prime material) in order to produce shoes for men and women, and do so in a large quantity. He already has a lot of requests for his work due to the good quality of his products.

Translated from Spanish by PULP Translators, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Compra de cueros y suelas

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy tablecloths, curtains, and other goods for resale.

loans.name: Sekea

texts.en: Mr. Sekea K. is a 42-year-old villager in Tonle village in Takeo Province, Cambodia. He and his wife, Mrs. Nget Van, are farmers who cultivate rice for a living. They have four children, one of whom is a teacher in the local school where the others are students.  Mr. Sekea K. decided to ask for a loan to buy fertilizer to make his land more productive and to hire some laborers to harvest the increased yield of rice.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and hire laborers to harvest rice.

loans.name: Ploak

texts.en:
Ploak S. is married and lives with three of her children and her husband in the Siem Reap province, Cambodia. She and her husband are farmers who grow rice and sugar cane and sell them to the market-wholesaler to earn a living and are able to make $5 each day. Ploak Savornn is pictured while she was drying her rice crops. This couple is also supported by their three children who work growing vegetables, in a hotel, and as a security guard at Angkor Temple.

Mrs. Ploak S. would like to take out a loan of $1000 to purchase a motorbike for her children to commute to work. This will allow them to save money, as before they used public transportation.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike.

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary O. sells textile materials, shoes, bags and a variety of other accessories and has been in business for over ten years. She sells in a store at a junction. She buys her goods from big cities like Kumasi and Accra in Ghana. She lives with her family in a town called Konongo in the Ashanti Region of Ghana. Mary is forty-two years old and married with four children, 3 girls, 1 boy. Two of her children are in their senior year of high school with the youngest in upper primary school. Mary’s husband is a teacher. 

Mary wants a loan to buy more bales of textiles to expand her business and sell at nearby markets to do more business.

loans.use: To buy more bales of textiles and accessories

loans.name: Maria Del Socorro

texts.es:
La señora María del Socorro E. tiene la edad de 38 años, su estado civil es casada, Doña María tiene 1 hijo de la edad de 10 años y cursa el 3 grado de primaria, su compañero de vida labora como ganadero, sus propósitos son de aumentar mas sus ganancias para sobrellevar la difícil situación del país ya que tiene que responsabilizarse por la manutención de sus hijos, sus sueños son de poseer estabilidad familiar por lo que hay muchos problemas entre ellos y le gustaría que algún día todos pudieran vivir unidos en una misma vivienda, sus deseos son de mejorar la calidad de vida de su familia ya que todos dependen de Doña María para realizar los gastos de su vivienda y su esposo le ayuda en lo que puede para que así juntos puedan sufragar los gastos de la familia también en sus deseos esta que su hijo pueda preparase para que sea un hombre que pueda servir con honor a su país.  

La actividad económica a la que Doña María se dedica es la venta de mercadería en general, la ubicación de su negocio es de manera ambulante, el tiempo que tiene  de poseer este negocio es de 9 años, Doña María dio inicio por motivo propio ya que tenia que buscar la forma de mantener a su familia y decide realizar la compra de ropa ya que no poseía el capital suficiente para comprar los suficientes productos y dio inicio con: ropa interior, pantalones y camisas para jóvenes por lo que recurrió a sus vecinos y amigos y mas por lo que mas tarde decide recurrir a los mercados para ofrecer sus productos ya que es aquí donde obtiene mas afluencias de clientes y cada día luchaba por obtener mas mercadería para mantener este negocio por lo que le gusto como medio de vida y como obtención de sus propósitos y mas tarde decide incrementar mas en su mercadería por lo que sus clientes le promocionaban una alta demanda, el financiamiento es para capital de trabajo propuesto para la compra de mas productos como: cosméticos, ropa para niños, camisas para jóvenes, pantalones para caballeros y otro productos por lo que también viaja a Managua en busca de lo mas favorable.
texts.en:
Mrs. Maria del Socorro E. is 38 years old. She is married and has one son who is ten year old. Her son is in the third grade and her husband works as a livestock farmer. Her goal is to increase her income and to be able to overcome the difficult economic situation in her country. Her dream is to be able to give her family a more stable life, since there are many problems in her family and she wishes that some day everyone will be able to live in the same home.Her dream is also to improve the quality of life for her family since everyone depends on her to pay for the costs of supporting the family. Her husband helps the family as much as he can. She really wishes the best for her son and hopes that he will become an honorable member of the community. Mrs. Maria's main economic activity is selling general merchandise. She is a traveling salesperson. She has had her business for the past nine years. She decided to start her business because she needed to find a way to provide for her family. She began by selling all types of clothing, but she didn't have the funds to buy enough items to sell, so she started by selling a few clothing items like underwear, jeans, and shirts for teens. She started selling to her neighbors and friends, but then moved on to markets where she was able to find more costumers. Everyday she works hard to obtain more merchandise to sell because she liked making a living this way. Now she wants to increase her inventory of merchandise even more because her clothing is in high demand. She wants this loan to be able to buy cosmetics, children's clothes, shirts for teens, men's jeans and other products that she can sell. She will travel to Managua where she can purchase the items at the lowest cost. (Translated by Elliot and Mariela of San Roque High School)

Translated from Spanish by Jay Osborne, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Capital for Business

loans.name: I Komang Wistra

texts.id: I Komang Wistra sudah menyelesaikan pinjamannya untuk tahap yang pertama. Pinjaman tersebut dipergunakan untuk biaya pengolahan tanah yang meliputi pembelian pupuk kimia, pupuk organik dan biaya untuk penyemprotan anti hama. Untuk masa tanam saat ini, pertumbuhan vanilinya bisa berkembang dengan baik karena mendapat perawatan yang optimal. Setiap tanaman vanili bisa menghasilkan 2 – 5 kilogram vanili basah. Panen yang lalu I Komang Wistra mendapatkan hasil 500 kilogram. Namun, saat ini harga vanili sangat rendah, yakni Rp. 5.000.- per kilogram. Jadi panen yang lalu I Komang Wistra hanya mendapatkan 500 x 5000 = Rp. 2.500.000.- Walaupun hasil yang didapat tidak sesuai dengan yang diharapkan, namun I Komang Wistra tidak terlalu bersedih karena dikebunnya terdapat juga pohon kakao yang juga mendapatkan perawatan dari biaya yang dikeluarkan untuk perawatan vanili. Pinjaman kedua ini I Komang Wistra berencana untuk lebih fokus untuk tanaman kakao karena hasilnya lebih baik dan harganya stabil. Pinjaman kedua ini dipergunakan untuk biaya pupuk dan bibit kakao untuk memperbanyak tanaman kakao yang sudah dimilikinya.
texts.en:
I Komang Wistra has fully paid off his 1st loan from DINARI foundation. He used that loan for his farming activities, buying organic and chemical fertilizer.As a result his vanilla farm (Vanilla planifolia) gives a good harvest. One vanilla plant can produce 2-5 KG vanilla. He harvested around 500 KG in the last harvest season. However due to the drop in vanilla price, I Komang Wistra only earned IDR 2.5 million from it (around USD 210).

I Komang Wistra is now planning to a new loan from DINARI. This time around he wants to focus on his Cacao plants. He switched to Cacao because cacao price is more stabile than vanilla. He is going to use this loan to buy more high quality cacao seed and fertilizer.

Translated from Indonesian by Antonius Gunadi, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: buy cacao seeds and fertilizer

loans.name: Amelia

texts.en:
Amelia S. is married to Romeo S.. They are both 46 years old. They live happily in a rural place located at Barangay Tuao North, Bagabag, Nueva Vizcaya. They are blessed with two children who are presently studying in the elementary level of education. As parents, it is their responsibility to send their children to school, hence, they need to work hard in order to provide the school needs of their children.

The common source of their income is through woodcraft or furniture making of tables, cabinets, 'sala' sets and other types of furniture. In the business they manage, the couple earn a net income of only 400 pesos weekly (roughly $US8) because they pay hired workers in the shop who help in making furniture for sale. The couple plans to improve their business in order to increase their income and also to help other unemployed workers out with educational attainment to support their families, too. However, the couple lacks the needed capital.

Learning about ASKI, the micro-finance institution providing the loan, Amelia came to realize that their plans are possible. She applied for a loan of 10,000 pesos for their furniture business. She is so glad for this opportunity and hopes for the progress of her business.

loans.use: To expand her furniture business.

loans.name: Odeola

texts.en: A. Odeola is 54 years old and married with 4 children.  She is a stylist. She has been in this business for a long time.  She lives in Ibadan, Oyo State.  She is requesting the loan amount of NGN 70,000 to purchase hair extensions and hair cream to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase hair extensions and hair cream to resell

loans.name: Jacob

texts.en: Jacob O. is 55 years old and married with five children. He has a sawmill where he sells wood planks. He is requesting a loan of $700 (100,000 NGN) to purchase more planks to sell. He would like to thank all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more wood planks to sell.

loans.name: Mohamed

texts.en: Mohamed A. works as a mechanic and sells car brake linings at Moree Junction which he has done since 1998.  He is married with 3 children and has received an education through Junior High School. While Mohamed works as a mechanic, his wife is employed as a "gari" (cassava grits) trader.  He is responsible for his family’s various financial expenses including the light bill and income tax. His loan will be used as additional capital to expand the business by acquiring more spare parts to aid in his repair work. He hopes to use his newly gained profits to further his children’s education.

loans.use: to expand the business by acquiring more spare parts

loans.name: Nida

texts.en: Nida M. resides at Manil, Leon B. Postigo. She is 48 years old and currently operates a small business store in her community. She has been able to raise four children, three of whom are already married. Her husband is a fisherman. Her store serves as the focal store in their community due to the fact that she is selling only primary commodities. She is planning to expand her store by selling also fishing equipment, since fishing is the primary source of income in their community. She hopes that she can provide more services to her neighbors.

loans.use: Additional capital on her sari-sari or retail business store.

location.town: Sindangan-Manil, Leon B. Postigo, Zamboanga del No

loans.name: Kossi Agbessi

texts.fr:
Ce monsieur exerce dans la menuiserie depuis 2007, il a ouvert son propre atelier. En dehors des commandes qu’il reçoit, il fabrique lui-même des meubles et des lits  qu’il expose devant son atelier pour attirer le regard des passants, actuellement son stock de matières nécessaires à son activité est épuisé. Il veut en acheter et demande pour cela un crédit à WAGES pour acheter 10 planches Teck, 05 planches Iroco, 05 planches acajou, 01 contre plaqué, 2 boîtes de vernis, 2 boîtes de diluant, 02 boîtes de colles.
Il est marié et père d’un enfant, c’est avec le revenu de son activité qu’il subvient aux charges de sa famille.
texts.en:
This is a gentleman who has been working in carpentry since 2007. He has opened his own workshop. Besides the orders he receives, he himself makes furniture and beds that he displays in front of his shop to attract customers. Currently, his stock of supplies necessary for his business is exhausted. He wants to buy some, and for this reason, he's asking WAGES for a loan to buy: 10 teak boards, 5 iroko wood boards, 5 cashew wood boards, 1 sheet of plywood, 2 cans of varnish, 2 cans of thinner, and 2 cans of glue. He is married and the father of one child. With the revenues from his business, he provides for his family.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy the necessary supplies for the woodworking business

loans.name: Ngô Thị

texts.en:
Lý Ngô Thị (233961443) is a 43 year-old female living in the town of Sóc Sơn.  She is married and has 2 school-aged children.  To making a living, Lý owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising livestock.  While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from raising pigs for sale.  Lý has been engaged in this business for over 13 years and earns approximately 5,000,000 VND a month from these activities.


In 1996, Lý joined TYM Fund to gain access to financial services to help improve  her living situation and ability to engage in business activities.  Lý has successfully repaid a previous loan of 20,000,000 VND from TYM Fund.  This previous loan was used to purchase breeding livestock.  Lý is now requesting a new loan of 20,000,000 VND which will be used to purchase baby livestock to raise & sell in future.  The loan will be the 13th loan taken out by her from TYM Fund.  Lý plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business.

loans.use: To purchase baby livestock to raise & sell in future.

loans.name: Ibrohim

texts.en: T. Ibrohim is married and is the father of four children. He works as a farmer everyday. He has a good work ethic and has whole-heartedly committed himself to agriculture. Thanks to his hard work, he has today become a man known for his determination and serves as an example and reference for other farmers. Ibrohim has been growing onions and potatoes for the past eleven years. He is now seeking a loan of 3,000 USD to buy seeds and fertilizer in the hope of producing a good harvest at the end of the season. He can then better meet the needs of his family and improve his working conditions. More about Tajikistan and IMON International Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium B.C. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions. But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty. IMON's History Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To purchase seeds and fertilizer

loans.name: Consorcia

texts.en:
Consorcia V. is a 57-year-old strong woman from the island village in the town of Binangonan, Rizal province in the Philippines. She is widowed and was left with four children to take care of. Her children were still young when her husband passed away. Now they are are all of legal age.

In 1995, she joined ASHI (Ahon Sa Hirap, Inc.), an MFI and Kiva partner in the Philippines, with hopes of having access to capital to start a business. Her previous loans were prudently utilized as rolling capital on her business of basket making made from bamboo. The business was tiring, laborious and time consuming considering her age. That is why, just recently, she shifted and ventured into a new business: the resale of charcoal and dressed chicken.

Now on her tenth loan, she requests loan of 45,000 pesos as additional capital for her primary business of reselling charcoal and dressed chicken. Specifically, the loan will use to pay for 200 sacks of charcoal and 100 kilos of dressed chicken plus labor and transportation expenses.

She is hopeful that her business will grow and may have space in the market. She also dreams of helping her grandchildren in their school fees and to save for her youngest daughter since she is a special child.

loans.use: To pay for 200 sacks of charcoal and 100 kilos of dressed chicken

loans.name: Aurelia Francisca

texts.es: Aurelia Francisca García tiene la actividad económica de venta de mercadería en general. Tiene 2 hijos a su cargo por lo que este es su principal fuente de ingresos para ayudar en los gastos de su familia. Este negocio surgió por la necesidad de trabajar, Por los gastos que tiene como madre para sus hijos. La ubicación de su negocio es de manera ambulante ya que este es el único método que le da resultados pues tiene que levantarse todos los días muy temprano para preparar las cosas que ofrecerá a sus clientes. Ella solicita este financiamiento para comprar cremas, colonias, ropa, calzado y cosméticos. Su mayor sueño es obtener un lugar en donde pueda ofrecer sus productos.
texts.en:
Aurelia Francisca García sells general merchandise. She has two children, and this is her primary source of income to help with the family expenses. This business emerged from the need to work for the expenses she has as the mother of her children. She sells on the street; that is the only method that gets results. Every day she needs to get up very early to prepare the things she offers her customers. She is asking for this loan to buy creams, colognes, clothes, footwear, and cosmetics. Her greatest dream to get a place where she can offer her products.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Working capital

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase commodities in bulk for her business

loans.name: Albertine

texts.fr: A. Albertine est née en 1969 à Allada dans le Département de l’Atlantique au Sud du Bénin. Albertine est mariée à LOKO Emmanuel, un instituteur. Albertine et son mari ont un enfant mais comme charge, ils ont deux enfants. La famille vit à Porto-Novo, Capitale Administrative du Bénin. Albertine vend de façon ambulante des tissus, des chaussures et des vêtements.  Albertine a eu déjà deux crédits de ALIDé ; crédits qu’elle a bien remboursés. Pour mieux développer son activité, Albertine sollicite un troisième crédit d’ALIDé pour renforcer son fonds de roulement.

loans.use: Achat de tissus, chaussures et vêtements.

loans.name: Ama Lébéne

texts.fr: Cette femme n’est pas mariée mais a un enfant à sa charge. C’est pour cette raison que l’année dernière, elle s’est lancée dans la vente d’huiles de palme (huile rouge) dans le marché de Hédzranawoé à Lomé. La plupart de ses clients apprécient la qualité et la bonne odeur que dégagent ses huiles. Elle met les huiles dans les bouteilles d’eau minérale et les revend ensuite. Elle prévoit dans l’avenir agrandir encore plus son commerce en vendant aussi des produits d’alimentation générale. Pour renouveler en ce moment son stock en baisse, elle sollicite un crédit de WAGES pour acheter 20 litres d’huile rouge.
texts.en:
This is a woman who is not married but has one child to support.  For this reason last year, she started selling palm oil (red oil) at the Hédzranawoé market in Lomé.  Most of her customers appreciate the quality and the nice aroma of her oils.  She puts the oils into mineral water bottles and then resells them.  In the future, she foresees expanding her commerce once more by selling grocery items as well.  To renew her low inventory right now, she's requesting a WAGES loan to buy 20 liters of red oil.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy palm oils

loans.name: Beatriz

texts.en:
Beatriz P. is from the village of Duanguican, Tudela, Misamis Occidental. She is 43 years old. Beatriz is married and has 9 school-aged children. To make a living, Beatriz owns and operates a general store. The main source of income for the business comes from selling daily use products such as shampoo, soap and toothpaste in the local community. Beatriz has been engaged in her business for over 2 years and earns approximately 2000 PHP a month for these activities.

Beatriz joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Beatriz has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. Beatriz is requesting a new loan of 7,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the 7th loan taken out by Beatriz from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Samuel

texts.en: Samuel is 26 years old. He is married and has a daughter who is in school. He lives with his wife and daughter in a rented apartment in a town called Kade, in the Eastern Region of Ghana. Kade is a commercial town. However, a majority of the residents practice farming as a hobby or as a major occupation alongside other trading activities. Samuel is a trader. He trades in fresh groundnuts. He supplies to retailers and food vendors in his community. He buys the groundnuts from nearby communities. Samuel has been in business for two years and wants a loan to procure goods in bulk to expand his business.

loans.use: To buy bags of groundnuts in bulk to expand his business

loans.name: Luz Maria

texts.es:
La señora  LUZ MARIA M. V., tiene  50 años, vive en el distrito de  MOCHE provincia de Trujillo, departamento La Libertad – Perú. La socia pertenece al Banco Comunal SIEMPRE ADELANTE  II. Ella presenta estudios hasta 5to de secundaria y  tiene 3  hijos, todos mayores. 
La socia tiene una tienda donde vende arroz, azúcar, fideos, menestras, golosinas, gaseosas, etc. El negocio lo tiene instalado en su casa.
Con su primer credito de 300.00 nuevos soles compró vitrinas y andamios.
Con este crédito de 550 nuevos soles comprará sacos de arroz al por mayor, aceite y cajas de cerveza al por mayor para estar abastecidas por las fiestas de fin de año.
Ella sueña con ampliar su tienda y poder vender todo lo que sus clientes le soliciten para así generar mayores ganancias.
texts.en:
Luz María Martínez Velásquez is 50 years old and she lives in Moche district, Trujillo province, La Libertad department, Peru. She is a member of the Siempre Adelante II communal bank. She studied through the 5th year of secondary school and she has 3 children, all grown. She has a store where she sells rice, sugar, noodles, vegetable stews, sweets, sodas, etc. The business is located in her house. Her first loan was for PEN 300.00 and she bought vitrine cases and shelving. With this loan of PEN 550.00 she will buy sacks of rice, cooking oil and cases of beer at wholesale prices, so that she will be well-stocked for the end-of-the-year festivities. She dreams of expanding her store and being able to sell everything that her customers request of her so that she can generate a better income.

Translated from Spanish by Jennifer Day, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy sacks of rice, cooking oil and cases of beer at wholesale prices

loans.name: Luna Radiante Group

texts.es: En uno de los Centros Focales de Pro Mujer Panamericana, se encuentra la Asociación Comunal Luna Radiante, que recientemente se formó para acceder al préstamo, esta integrada por 7 mujeres y 1 varón liderizadas por su mesa directiva desarrollan su reunión ordenadamente, así la  presidenta es María A., Tesorera es Maria Y.  y ocupando la cartera de Secretario de Actas está  Elisa T., indican que formaron el grupo por la necesidad de contar con un capital de trabajo para mejorar sus niveles de ingreso, así todos tienen diferentes actividades económicas de producción, comercialización y servicios, esperan invertir el préstamo en sus negocios para hacer crecer el mismo.
texts.en:
La Asociación Comunal Luna Radiante meets at one of Pro Mujer Panamericana's Focal Centers. The group formed recently to gain access to credit. The group includes 7 women and 1 man. Led by their Executive Board, they carry out their meetings in an orderly fashion. The president is María A., the treasurer is Maria Y. and the secretary is Elisa T.. They indicate that they formed the group because they needed working capital to improve their income. They all have different economic activities in production, marketing and services. They hope to invest the loan in their businesses to make them grow.

Translated from Spanish by Jennifer Chong, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of merchandise and primary materials

loans.name: Argelia María

texts.es:
El mes de Diciembre es muy alegre porque se celebra la navidad y muchas familias deciden mejorar las condiciones de su vivienda como es el caso de la señora Argelia que ha tomado la iniciativa de mejorar las condiciones de su vivienda para que en esta navidad luzca muy bonita y las personas que le lleguen a visitar puedan ver el cambio en su vivienda.
Ella está solicitando el crédito para dar lugar a la compra de los materiales de construcción y de esta forma llevar a cabo la obra de reconstrucción de su casa para satisfacción de ella y de su familia.
texts.en:
The month of December is very happy because Christmas is celebrated and many families decide to improve the home’s condition, like in the case of Ms. Argelia. She has taken the initiative to improve the condition of her home, so that this Christmas, it looks very nice and so that the people who come to visit can see the change in her home. She is requesting this loan to purchase construction materials and to carry out the renovation on the house to the satisfaction of Argelia and her family.

Translated from Spanish by Lauren Jackson, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to buy construction materials

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: The loan will be used to purchase beauty and hairstyling products.

loans.name: Sokhom's Group

texts.en:
This loan group, which consists of nine people, is lead by Mrs. Sokhom C.. She is 45 years old and she lives in Pech Changva Village, TaK. Province. Mrs. Sokhom C. and her husband, Mr. Hor Tuon, are farmers who own a piece of land on which they grow rice. They now face a problem because their field has infertile soil, so Mrs. Sokhom C. decided to ask for a loan to buy fertilizer. With the rest of the loan, she will buy fuel to support the crops on her farm. Mrs. Sokhom C. is a mother of four childrE.. One of her childrE. is employed in a garment factory and the other three are students in the local school. Mrs. Pho Pha, who is the group guarantor, is also presented in the photo with the village bank loan group members. 

[Editor's Note: Group guarantors are usually clients who have established a credit history. They guarantee the loans of clients who have less credit history, enabling those clients to take out their first loan or a larger loan. If a member of the loan group cannot pay, the guarantor will share some responsibility for the debt.]

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and fuel

loans.name: Marata

texts.en:
Marata L. is 52 and married with 4 children (ages 11 - 26).  She owns a business venture, selling fine mats used as keepsakes .  Marata has 3 years of experience in this business.  Marata needs a loan of WST $1500 to buy laufala (plant fibres) and decorations for mats.  She plans to use the earnings from her business (estimated to be 450 talas or US $188 per week) to improve/expand the business.

In 2009, Marata joined SPBD.    This is her 3rd loan with SPBD.   SPBD's loans are Marata's only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with traditional banks.

The following social metrics for Marata L. are provided by SPBD*:
Overall Social Metric Score:                1.5 out of 3
Level of Education:                         1.5 out of 3
Level of total Household Income:            1.5 out of 3
Quality of Household Assets:                2.5 out of 3

*SPBD measures the living conditions of each of its borrowers to track her loan progress. The overall social metric score, provided by SPBD, is based upon a number of factors, such as the condition of the house/household assets, health, education, income level, and family reputation. A higher number represents a higher score. For example, a ""3 out of 3"" on education would mean that the borrower has graduated from university; a ""2 out of 3"" = secondary/high-school, and a ""1 out of 3"" would mean that the borrower is uneducated.

For more information on this score, please see SPBD's partner page at: http://partners.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=15

About SPBD
In 2000, Greg Casagrande founded SPBD and since then, it has expanded from the main island of Upolu in Samoa to Savaii, as well as Tonga. SPBD's philosophy of lending is based upon the Grameen Bank lending method.

Please join SPBD's lending team on KIVA to receive on-the-spot updates on SPBD: http://www.kiva.org/community/viewTeam?team_id=8375

loans.use: to buy laufala (plant fibres) and decorations for mats

loans.name: Paulina

texts.en:
Paulina S. is currently in the business of selling beer at home and is requesting a loan to stock more crates of beer to sell. Paulina is 29 years old and is married with a husband that is a teacher. She has four children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build up a bar at the market.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services that are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To buy more crates of beer to sell.

loans.name: Moses

texts.en: Moses is a 31-year-old hardworking man who offers motorbike transport to his area residents.  He previously acquired a motorbike using the loan he took out from Faulu Kenya.  He is the breadwinner in his family and he has three children in school.  He uses his income to support his family.  He plans to buy a new motorbike to make his services efficient. Therefore, he has requested a loan of Kes 85,000 from Faulu Kenya.  He dreams of investing in the taxi business in the future.

loans.use: To buy a new motorbike

loans.name: Lao

texts.en:
Mr. Lao N. is a married man of 37 years who lives in the capital of Phnom Penh. (Lao N. was not available for photographing so his wife is pictured instead.)       

To make a daily net profit, Lao N. works as a temporarily laborer in the construction filed and typically earns $2.50 or $3 per day. He is married to Sreythom, age 33, a garment worker. They have a school-aged child. 

Every day, the family finds it hard traveling to work because they have no vehicle. To solve this problem, Lao N. decided to ask for a loan of $800 to be used to buy a modern motorcycle, which will allow him and his family to commute to their work location or anywhere else.

loans.use: To buy a modern motorcycle

loans.name: Abdallah

texts.en:
Abdallah is a 28-year-old married man with one child. He has been working in agriculture for the past ten years.

In 2004, Abdallah started working as a farmer, cultivating all types of vegetables and fruits, and he distributes the harvest in an agriculture market. He has built special agricultural tents for the cultivation process. 

Today, Abdallah is requesting $1,000 to purchase additional agricultural tents to increase his cultivation before the coming summer season.

loans.use: To purchase additional agricultural tents

loans.name: Dim Din Group

texts.en:
Meet with members of “Dim Din” group. They are local entrepreneurs in Waterloo, a small town near Freetown, where “Shine on Sierra Leone” has partnered with SMT to start a branch.  They have applied for their first SMT/Kiva loan. With the help of this loan, they will be able to add more goods to their business inventories, make more sales and consequently improve their standard of living. They are requesting a loan of SLL 500,000 for each in the group in order to buy more goods to add to their businesses.

Their leader is Haja K. (pictured left). She is 29 years old. Haja sells palm oil (the most popular cooking oil) and peppers. She has been a businesswoman for ten years now. With her share of the loan, she will buy gallons of palm oil and bags of peppers to add to her business.  

Haja was born in Freetown, the capital city of Sierra Leone. She is married to a building contractor and they have three children; one of their children is in class II, the second is in nursery school, and the youngest is not of school going age. 

(Attached to this photo is a snapshot of a borrower who was not able to be present for the group photo.)

loans.use: Buy gallons of palm oil and bags of peppers for resale

loans.name: Keo

texts.en:
Keo C., 38, is married and resides with her husband and three children in Phnom Penh City, the most populated city in Cambodia. She is a civil service employee who earns an income of about USD 6 per day.

C. is requesting a loan of USD 1000 to purchase a motorbike to commute to work. In the future she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house. This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

[C.'s husband appears in the photograph.]

loans.use: To buy a motorbike to commute to work.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To purchase additional inventory and to use as working capital

loans.name: Hassan

texts.en:
Hassan is a married man with four children; three of  whom attend school while one is still too young for school. His spouse is a businesswoman and she contributes to the family's basic needs. Hassan has been operating a vegetable stall for the last five years, selling vegetables to the neighboring community. Farming was his previous occupation.


With the Kshs. 40,000 he wants to purchase a bundle of vegetables, tomatoes and potatoes. High transport costs were cited as his major challenge in  business.


Hassan hopes to own a wholesale shop in future. He decided to work with Yehu because it is simple to join and offers accessibility to sustainable financial services. 


He owns a house with no electricity and piped water. His greatest monthly expense is food.

loans.use: To purchase vegetables

loans.name: Shamim Akhtar's Group

texts.en:
Shamim akhtar lives in a two room cement house with her six children and her husband, M. I., in a city in Pakistan named Borewala. Shamim has three daughters and three sons.  I. owns a business selling crockery and in his business his three sons also help out. I. has eight years experience in selling crockery.  

Shamim is a housewife. She takes care of her house and her three daughters who are in their twenties. They help their mother with the work which gives Shamim a proud feeling.

She has taken three loans from ASASAH and successfully repaid them and maintained a good credit performance continuously for three years. Now she has applied for a fourth loan from Asasah for her husband and sons. With the loan they will buy crockery in bulk and their own shop in themarket to earn a better profit. 

From the profit earned from the last three loans, Shamim and her family bought a color television and renovated their house.

loans.use: To purchase crokery for reselling

loans.name: Davaanyam

texts.en:
Davaanyam S. is 26 years old and lives in Uvs province, western Mongolia, together with his parents in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent.

Davaanyam operates a wooden product making business, including ger accessories, in his town. The business is very family oriented, as his father designs their products while Davaanyam paints and decorates them, and his mother sews traditional Mongolian boots. He and his family also plant vegetables along with the wooden products business. Davaanyam started his wood products business in 2009 and expanded his business into making walls, upper walls, and poles for Mongolian gers. The business has been successful and they have grown a stable operation. Davaanyam attributes his success to the quality of his products, which is much desired by his customers. He is requesting a 350,000 MNT loan to purchase more wood and paints for their wooden products business.

loans.use: To purchase inventory.

loans.name: Cecilia

texts.en: Cecilia R. is currently in the business of selling charcoal, bread, and dried fish at home and is requesting a loan to stock more bags of charcoal to sell.  Cecilia is 41 years old and is Married with a husband that is a peasant. She has four children who all go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to pay the school fees for her children.

loans.use: stock more bags of charcoal to sell

loans.name: Maribeth

texts.en: Maribeth A. is a married woman who lives in Purok 3, Barangay Tumarbong, Roxas, Palawan. She earns her living by operating two business ventures: a piggery and a food-vending business. Her husband, Miguel A., who is 40 years old, works as a farmer and also helps in his wife's business activities. They have six children who are between 4 months and 17 years old. Maribeth joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2007 because she wished for something better for her family. With the help of her past five loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, she has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 11,000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 14,000, uplifting her family's standard of living. This time, for her 6th loan, Maribeth is borrowing PHP 13,500, which she intends to use to purchase feeds and vitamins for her pigs so that she can continue to save for the future education of her children and to put up a general store. Maribeth is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams. About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress out of earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue in its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by visiting the NWTF lending team on Kiva to join our team.

loans.use: To purchase feeds and vitamins for her pigs

loans.name: Williams Antonio

texts.es: Williams Antonio es un hombre muy trabajador y que está muy contento con medio de vida. El se dedica a ofrecer los servicios de carpintería, pues siempre está al pendiente de lo que sus clientes le solicitan. El inicio hace mas de 12 años lo aprendió por medio de su amigo, con el paso del tiempo es que decide establecer su propio medio de ingreso y así ayudar con los gastos del hogar pues siempre sus clientes le solicitan diferentes pedidos. El solicita este crédito para la compra de madera, clavos, pega, tornillos y herramientas que son necesarias para realizar sillas, camas, escritorio, mesas y cunas.
texts.en:
Williams Antonio is a very hard-working man, and he is very happy with his line of work. He is a carpenter, and he devotes himself to his customers’ requests. He started over 12 years ago, and he learned from his friend. As time passed, he decided to establish his own means of income to help with the household expenses. His customers always make different requests. He is asking for this loan to buy wood, nails, glue, screws, and the necessary tools to make chairs, beds, desks, tables, and cribs.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Work capital

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
This Kiva borrower is a 42-year-old married man and the father of four children of whom two are still attending school. He makes his living as an experienced taxi driver. He has been involved in this business for the past 15 years. His main service route is between his town and the surrounding areas. And he also offers private transportation services. 

Today, he is requesting to borrow US$ 1000 from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l. to perform maintenance work on his taxi including changing the tires and repairing the engine.

loans.use: to perform maintenance work on his taxi

loans.name: Ko'e Pyahu Kuñakuerape Group

texts.es:
Las mujeres del presente comité son de Piribebuy.
Las señoras de este comité son mujeres muy honestas y sacrificadas, cada una de ellas trabajan arduamente para aumentar sus ingresos y así aportar un poco más a su unidad familiar, algunas salen a vender comestibles, otras venden ropas, otras tienen pequeñas despensas y kioscos y las demás se dedican a la fabricación y venta de detergentes, suavizantes, desodorante de ambiente etc.  
Las integrantes del comité están muy felices de participar del programa y están muy agradecidas con Fundación Paraguaya por tan importante apoyo que les está brindando.  
Una de las integrantes es la Sra. Rossana quien se dedica a la venta de ropas desde ya hace bastante tiempo y teniendo en cuenta la calidad y precios bajos de sus mercaderías posee una buena clientela.
La misma desea incrementar sus ingresos mediante la adquisición al por mayor cantidad y variedad de mercaderías de la temporada primavera-verano, para satisfacer la demanda y tambie para abaratar los precios.
Solicita el préstamo para la compra de mercaderias como remeras, shorts, blusas, vestidos, y otros.
De esta forma seguirá ampliando el negocio.
texts.en:
The women of this committee are from Piribebuy. They are honest and selfless; each works very hard to raise her income and thus contribute a little more to her family. Some go out to sell food, others sell clothing, others have small general stores and kiosks, and the rest make and sell detergents, fabric softeners, air fresheners, etc. 

The members of the committee are very pleased to be participating in the program and are very grateful to the Paraguay Foundation for the important support that it provides them. 

One of the members is Ms. Rossana, who has sold clothing for a long time. She has built a good clientele because she sells quality merchandise at low prices. Rossana wants to increase her income through the wholesale purchase of a large quantity and variety of spring-summer merchandise, thereby satisfying demand and lowering prices. 

She requests the loan to purchase merchandise such as t-shirts, shorts, blouses, and dresses. In doing so, Rossana will continue growing her business.

loans.use: To purchase clothes in bulk for the spring-summer season to resell

loans.name: Grace

texts.en:
Grace P. is 36 years old, married, and supports her family by operating one business venture: a pottery business.  She lives in Sitio Tuburan, Brgy. Camba-og, Hinigaran, Negros Occidental. She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 1999 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. 

By working hard in her pottery business, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of PHP 8,000. Grace is now borrowing PHP 14,000 so that she can continue to fund the operations of her business. This will be her 16th loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of PHP 14,000, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey toward economic freedom. Grace aspires to elevate her family's living conditions and ensure their future well-being by following the Dungganon way. 

About NWTF: 

In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed on a member of a community who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking  the link to the   NWTF Kiva lending team  on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: Fund the operations of her pottery business

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to purchase additional fish to sell

loans.name: Kankélé Group

texts.fr:
Kankélé est un regroupement de femmes du quartier Darsalam de Koutiala qui se connaissent bien. Elles  vivent dans de grandes familles traditionnelles avec leurs maris, enfants et autres parents. Elles ont en moyenne 37 ans, sont mariées et mères d’au moins 5 enfants.
Ce groupe de femmes fait le commerce d’articles divers tels, les chaussures, les légumes, les habillements, les cosmétiques etc. 
Pour augmenter la taille de leurs activités, les membres ont décidé d’intégrer le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso il y a 2 ans. Elles sont à leur cinquième prêt de groupe et tous les quatre prêts précédents  ont été bien remboursés. 
Mariam D., qui est la présidente du groupe Kankélé vend de la friperie de draps de lits, d’habits  pour enfants, de pull-overs pour  hommes et femmes etc,  est très sollicitée et appréciée dans la ville de Koutiala.  
Elle compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter, une balle de pull-overs surtout en cette période de froid. Elle se procure  de cette balle à Bamako (la capitale malienne).  Elle vend ses articles en détail et au comptant au grand marché de Koutiala et à la maison à une clientèle diverse et variée. 
Tandis que Les membres du groupe Kankélé comptent réaliser un bénéfice moyen de 140 000FCFA  chacune au  cours de ce cycle, Mariam D. compte réaliser 160 000FCFA. de bénéfice.
En plus du remboursement des prêts, elles utilisent une partie du revenu  pour faire face aux dépenses courantes de la famille. 
Elles souhaitent renforcer leurs partenariats avec Soro Yiriwaso pour pouvoir diversifier leurs marchandises.
texts.en:
Kankélé is a group of women from the Darsalam neighborhood of Koutiala who know each other well.  They live in large traditional families with their husbands, children, and other relatives.  They have an average age of 37 and are married with at least 5 children.

This group of women sells various articles such as shoes, vegetables, clothing, cosmetics, etc.  To increase the scale of their business, the members decided two years ago to participate in the Soro Yiriwaso credit program.  They are on their fifth group loan and all four of the previous loans have been repaid.

Mariam D., the president of the Kankélé group, sells secondhand sheets, children's clothing, men's and women's sweaters, etc.  She is very popular and appreciated in the village of Koutiala.  She plans to use her loan to purchase a bale of sweaters for the current colder period.  She will obtain the bale in Bamako, the capital.  She sells these products on a retail and credit basis in the Koutiala market and at home to a diverse clientele.  While the members of the Kankélé group expect to make an average profit of 140,000FCFA each during this cycle, Mariam D. expects to make a profit of 160,000FCFA.

Besides repaying the loans, the women use a part of the revenue to meet family expenses.  They wish to strengthen their partnership with Soro Yiriwaso in order to diversify their products.

loans.use: Purchase of secondhand clothing

loans.name: Edith

texts.en:
Edith S. lives in the Nalukolongo neighborhood in the city of Kampala, Uganda.  She is married and has two children, both of whom are in school.  She also takes care of additional family members. 

Edith has a business selling charcoal and has been in this business for ten years.  Edith has requested a loan of 2000000 Ugandan Shillings from MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy more bags of charcoal. She also generates additional income through renting rooms. 

The main business challenges for Edith include the rainy season and transportation. Her goals and aspirations for her business are to start selling wholesale only and to own a delivery van. 

Edith lives  in a home that she owns.  She doesn’t have access to electricity or piped water.  Her major monthly expenses include school fees, food, and medication.

loans.use: To buy charcoal to sell

loans.name: Adidas

texts.en:
Adidas is 32 years old and is married. She sells beans. Adidas has been in this business for about four years and her store is open from 7am to 4pm every day except on Sunday, and she currently employs two people.

Adidas will use this loan to expand her business by adding more beans. Any profits made from the use of this loan will be reinvested in her business.

She thanks you for your support!

loans.use: To purchase more beans to sell.

loans.name: Dionicio

texts.en:
Dionicio G. is from the village of Esperanza West, Aurora, Isabela. He is 35 years old. Dionicio is married and has 1 young child. To make a living, Dionicio owns & operates a business, primarily planting and harvesting rice for sale. Dionicio has been engaged in his business for over 5 years and earns approximately 3000 PHP every harvest season.

In 2010, Dionicio joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and his ability to engage in business activities. Dionicio is requesting a new loan of 15000 PHP, which will be used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. This will be the 1st loan taken out by Dionicio from ASKI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand his business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers, such as manure.

loans.name: Nora

texts.es: Nora, es una mujer única siempre fuerte e imponente, ella tiene 43 años, y en compañía de su esposo Percy, salen adelante en su casa propia ubicada en el caserío de Patay. A pesar de que su esposo trabaja en otra ciudad y no tiene mayores necesidades, está trabajadora mujer le gusta ser independiente y luchadora. Hace 20 años que se dedica a la agricultura, donde comenzó junto a su esposo a sembrar productos oriundos de la zona como: flor de gladiolo, habas, arvejas y papa; pero hace algunos años Percy, se fue a trabajar fuera de la ciudad, dejando en manos de Nora el cuidado de sus terrenos agrícolas, los que gracias a su buen juicio logró sacar adelante. Una vez al mes viaja a la capital a vender lo que ha cosechado. Por toda la capacidad que está demostrando desea en adelante mejorar sus sembríos y así poder generar mejores ganancias. Ella pertenece al banco comunal “Picaflores de Patay”, y este es el cuarto préstamo que tienen con MFP, donde asume la secretaría de su asociación, siendo una integrante responsable y muy comprometida. Nora muy pronto cosechará habas y papa. Todo el capital que tiene lo invertirá en la fertilización de sus plantaciones para que le den un buen fruto; por ello con el crédito solicitado, comprará una bolsa de semilla de arveja, que esparcirá entre sus sembríos después de la cosecha.
texts.en: Nora,is a unique, always strong and imposing woman.  She is 43 years old, and, along with her husband Percy, they do well in their own house located in the settlement of Patay.  In spite of the fact that her husband works in another city and she does not have basic necessities, this hard-working woman likes to be independent and a fighter.  For twenty years she has been dedicated to agriculture, which she began along with her husband sowing native products of the zone such as: gladiolus flowers, beans, peas and potatoes.   But some years ago Percy went to work away from the city, leaving the care of their agricultural lands in the hands of Nora. Thanks to her good judgment she managed to move ahead.  Once a month she travels to the capital to sell what she has harvested.  For all the capacity that she is showing she desires to improve her sown fields and thus to be able to generate better profits.  She belongs to the communal bank "Hummingbirds of Patay", and this is the fourth loan that she has had with MFP, where she assumes the office of the secretary of her association, being a responsible member and very agreeable.  Nora very soon will harvest beans and potatoes.  All the capital that she has will be invested it in the fertilization of her crops so that they give her a good yield.  Because of this she requests a loan to buy a sack of seed for peas which she will spread in her fields after the crop is harvested.

loans.use: To buy seeds for peas.

loans.name: Liz

texts.es:
La señora Liz es socia  del banco comunal Mujeres Solidarias, del Distrito Calleria, Departamento de Ucayali, tiene 42 años de edad y tiene 3 hijos que todavía están a su cargo.
Se dedica a la compra y venta de madera,  en este trabajo son más conocidos como corredores de madera, lleva trabajando con los préstamos de Manuela Ramos hace 3 años.  El trabajo es duro, sin embargo se siente muy satisfecha con los resultados.
trabaja desde muy temprano hasta las nueve o diez de la noche, no tiene una hora fija de regresar a su casa, tiene que trabajar así porque ella es la que mantiene su hogar, porque está separada del  padre de sus hijos.
Con este nuevo préstamo de S/. 1000.00 nuevos soles comprará una moto  de segunda mano para poder movilizarse, porque el gasto en pasajes es demasiado alto, casi todo el día esta de un lugar a otro.
Puede dejar su casa tranquila porque su hija mayor se encarga de los que aceres de su casa, por esa parte tiene una gran ayuda.
Manuela Ramos ha sido de gran ayuda para mejorar la situación económica de su familia.
texts.en:
Liz is a member of the “Mujeres Solidarias” (Mutually Supportive Women) communal bank in Callería district, Ucayali department.  She’s 42 years old and has three children still in her care.

She is a lumber merchant, better known in this job as a lumber agent.  She has been working with Manuela Ramos loans for three years.  The work is hard.  However, she feels very satisfied with the results she’s had.  She works from very early until nine or ten at night.  She does not have a fixed time to return home.  She has to work like this because she’s the one that supports the household because she’s separated from her children’s father.

She will use this new 1000 new sol loan to buy a second hand motorcycle to get around on because her transportation costs are too high; she spends almost the entire day going from here to there.

She can leave her house with peace of mind because her oldest daughter does the household chores so in this she has great help.

Manuela Ramos has been of great help for her to improve her family’s economic situation.

loans.use: To buy a second hand motorcycle.

loans.name: Chak's Group

texts.en:
